Improvement Noted
In Hospital Finances
Despite a record high operating cost of $15,100,000, the Johns
Hopkins Hospital saw marked
improvement in its financial position during fiscal year 1960-61.
The treasurer's report for the
fiscal year ending June 30, 1961,
shows that, while the cost of
running the Hospital increased 8
per cent, operating income more
than kept pace by climbing almost 9 per cent from the 195960 period to $14,100,000.
The resulting $1,000,000 operating loss compares with a loss
of $1,456,000 in 1960 and $1,610,000 in 1959. Gifts and endowment income reduced the Hospital's operating loss to a net loss
of $30,000, the lowest in eight
years.
But, the treasurer's report emphasizes, the use of endowment

income and gifts to offset operating loss deprives the Hospital of
a source of funds for needed improvements in existing facilities.
Almost half of the Hospital's
rise in operating expenses was
accounted for by an increase in
salaries and wages paid to 2,805
employees. The Hospital's payroll
rose to $8,551,569, and increase
of 7 per cent ( $564,000) over the
previous year. Most of this increase came from higher wage
scales adopted by Johns Hopkins
on January 1, 1961.
Much of the operating loss resulted from $761,000 worth of
free medical care provided to
patients who could not qualify
for aid under the state's indigent
program and who had little or no
hospitalization insurance.

With the help of a U.S. Public
Health Service grant of $77,050,
a Johns Hopkins School of Medicine neurosurgery group has
launched a broad study aimed at
understanding the cause of the
epileptic fit. The project is
headed by Dr. A. Earl Walker.
professor of neurosurgery.
Epilepsy, which afflicts about
1,500,000 persons in the United
States, is one of the least understood nerve disorders. It is basically an impairment of brain cell
function.
Its
understa.nding
probably lies in solving the subtle interplay of brain cell chemistry and physics.
Medical men see the epileptic
fit as arising from electrical disturbances in several areas of the
brain. Abnormal discharges are
sent to various parts of the body.
giving rise to the familiar epileptic convulsions.
The work of Dr. Walker and
his group will entail studies on
the monkey, the chimpanzee,and
the epileptic human. Included
among the several studies will
be:
--Detection of changes in the
amounts of certain key enzymes
in brain cells during the fit.
Enzymes are proteins that control and balance the speeds of
every reaction in every cell of
the body.
--New analysis of the electrical activity of those portions of
the brain distributed during the
fit—in other words, new encephalograms — and determination
of the effects of certain drugs on
the electrical patterns.

drizzle, snow and sleet—all at the twist
of dials. Huge cylinders beneath testcar wheels imitate every kind of road:

mountain trail.

build better cars—cars that are built to
last longer, require less care, and retain
their value better. This constant aiming
for perfection is just one more way in

Second Semester Rush?
The Inter-fraternity Council, in attempts to improve a deficient system, has made minor revisions in
its rushing procedure during the last few years. However, despite these well meaning attempts, the primary
deficiencies of Hopkins fraternity rushing still remain
outstanding. Depending upon one's point of view, the
first semester rush is either too long and drawn out
or too short to make the proper choice, either too concentrated or not enough so, etc. But perhaps most crucial
of all, it really does not give freshmen adequate opportunity to see the various fraternities as they actually
live and operate. Most freshmen select rather haphazardly or prefer to enter open rushing.
There are several courses of action open to the
IFC at this point. The most obvious is experimentation
with second semester rushing, but there are other systems
which deserve consideration. A survey of other universities having similar fraternity set-ups might be in order.
If the second semester system is introduced, careful
precautions must be taken to prevent the first semester
from becoming one long secret, or not so secret, rush
season. This happens on many campuses and can become a burden on both actives and freshmen. The IFC
must determine whether the advantages of such a system
outweigh its disadvantages, something which might have
to be done by actual experimentation.

Are you still writing "1961" on your papers and letters? I'll
bet you are, you scamps! But I am not one to be harsh with
those who forget we are in a new year, for I myself have long
been guilty of the same lapse. In fact, in my senior year at
college, I wrote 1873 on my papers until nearly November of
1874! (It turned out, incidentally, not to be such a serious
error because, as we all know, 1874 was later repealed by
President Chester A. Arthur in a fit of pique over the Black
Tom Explosion. And, as we all know, Mr. Arthur later came
to regret his hasty action. Who does not recall that famous
meeting between Mr. Arthur and Louis Napoleon when Mr.
Arthur said, "Lou, I wish I hadn't of repealed 1874." Whereupon the French emperor made his immortal rejoinder, "Tipi
Tie nous et tyler tu." Well sir, they had many a good laugh
about that, as you can imagine.)
But I digress. How can we remember to write 1962 on our
papers and letters? Well sir, the best way is to find something
memorable about 1962, something unique to fix it firmly in
your mind. Happily, this is very simple because, as we all know,
1962 is the first year in history that is divisible by 2, by 4, and
by 7. Take a pencil and try it: 1962 divided by 2 is 981; 1962
divided by 4 is 490-1/2; 1962 divided by 7 is 280-2/7.This mathematical curiosity will not occur again until the year 2079, but
we will all be so busy then celebrating the Chester A. Arthur

hi-centenary that we will scarcely have time to be writing
papers and letters and like that.
Another clever little trick to fix the year 1962 in your mind
is to remember that 1962 spelled backwards is 2691. "Year"
spelled backwards is "raey." "Marlboro" spelled backwards is
"oroblram." Marlboro smoked backwards is no fun at all.
Kindly do not light the filter. What you do is put the filter end
in your lips, then light the tobacco end, then draw, and then
find out what pleasure, what joy, what rapture serene it is to
smoke the filter cigarette with the unfiltered taste. In 1962, as
in once and future years, you'll get a lot to like in a Marlboro—
available in soft pack and flip-top box in all 50 states and
Duluth.

of 1962 and high among them, of course, is the fact that in

but none, I'll wager, quite so lively and interesting as the one
in my own district where the leading candidate is none other
than Chester A. Arthur!

out of retirement and run for the House of Representatives.
John Quincy Adams was the first. Mr. Adams also holds
another distinction: he was the first son of a president ever to

launched a broad study aimed at
understanding the cause of the
epileptic fit. The project is
headed by Dr. A. Earl Walker.

function.

understa.nding
probably lies in solving the subtle interplay of brain cell chemistry and physics.

sent to various parts of the body.
giving rise to the familiar epileptic convulsions.

his group will entail studies on
the monkey, the chimpanzee,and
the epileptic human. Included
among the several studies will
be:
--Detection of changes in the
amounts of certain key enzymes
in brain cells during the fit.
Enzymes are proteins that control and balance the speeds of
every reaction in every cell of
the body.
--New analysis of the electrical activity of those portions of
the brain distributed during the
fit—in other words, new encephalograms — and determination
of the effects of certain drugs on
the electrical patterns.

Second Semester Rush?
The Inter-fraternity Council, in attempts to improve a deficient system, has made minor revisions in
its rushing procedure during the last few years. However, despite these well meaning attempts, the primary
deficiencies of Hopkins fraternity rushing still remain
outstanding. Depending upon one's point of view, the
first semester rush is either too long and drawn out
or too short to make the proper choice, either too concentrated or not enough so, etc. But perhaps most crucial
of all, it really does not give freshmen adequate opportunity to see the various fraternities as they actually
live and operate. Most freshmen select rather haphazardly or prefer to enter open rushing.
There are several courses of action open to the
IFC at this point. The most obvious is experimentation
with second semester rushing, but there are other systems
which deserve consideration. A survey of other universities having similar fraternity set-ups might be in order.
If the second semester system is introduced, careful
precautions must be taken to prevent the first semester
from becoming one long secret, or not so secret, rush
season. This happens on many campuses and can become a burden on both actives and freshmen. The IFC
must determine whether the advantages of such a system
outweigh its disadvantages, something which might have
to be done by actual experimentation.

Are you still writing "1961" on your papers and letters? I'll
bet you are, you scamps! But I am not one to be harsh with
those who forget we are in a new year, for I myself have long
been guilty of the same lapse. In fact, in my senior year at
college, I wrote 1873 on my papers until nearly November of
1874! (It turned out, incidentally, not to be such a serious
error because, as we all know, 1874 was later repealed by
President Chester A. Arthur in a fit of pique over the Black
Tom Explosion. And, as we all know, Mr. Arthur later came
to regret his hasty action. Who does not recall that famous
meeting between Mr. Arthur and Louis Napoleon when Mr.
Arthur said, "Lou, I wish I hadn't of repealed 1874." Whereupon the French emperor made his immortal rejoinder, "Tipi
Tie nous et tyler tu." Well sir, they had many a good laugh
about that, as you can imagine.)
But I digress. How can we remember to write 1962 on our
papers and letters? Well sir, the best way is to find something
memorable about 1962, something unique to fix it firmly in
your mind. Happily, this is very simple because, as we all know,
1962 is the first year in history that is divisible by 2, by 4, and
by 7. Take a pencil and try it: 1962 divided by 2 is 981; 1962
divided by 4 is 490-1/2; 1962 divided by 7 is 280-2/7.This mathematical curiosity will not occur again until the year 2079, but
we will all be so busy then celebrating the Chester A. Arthur

hi-centenary that we will scarcely have time to be writing
papers and letters and like that.
Another clever little trick to fix the year 1962 in your mind
is to remember that 1962 spelled backwards is 2691. "Year"
spelled backwards is "raey." "Marlboro" spelled backwards is
"oroblram." Marlboro smoked backwards is no fun at all.
Kindly do not light the filter. What you do is put the filter end
in your lips, then light the tobacco end, then draw, and then
find out what pleasure, what joy, what rapture serene it is to
smoke the filter cigarette with the unfiltered taste. In 1962, as
in once and future years, you'll get a lot to like in a Marlboro—
available in soft pack and flip-top box in all 50 states and
Duluth.

of 1962 and high among them, of course, is the fact that in

but none, I'll wager, quite so lively and interesting as the one
in my own district where the leading candidate is none other
than Chester A. Arthur!

out of retirement and run for the House of Representatives.
John Quincy Adams was the first. Mr. Adams also holds
